awd_titl_txt: Reducing Achievement Gaps in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM): Promising International Research, Policies and Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging in hands-on field experience, laboratory/project-based entrepreneurship tasks and mentorship experiences.

Georgia Institute of Technology (U.S.) and Yildiz Technical University (Turkey) propose an international conference to provide a forum for ministers of education, researchers, and practitioners from countries with high- medium- and low-STEM achievement scores to assess the problem of achievement gaps in STEM disciplines from a global perspective and to develop more global solutions share information.  This conference will identify major challenges and opportunities for addressing the achievement gap that exist among racial/ethnic, socio-economic status and gender and subsequently suggest solutions and strategies to provide all children equal opportunities to acquire knowledge and develop STEM skills. More specifically, the major goals of the conference are to: (a) identify major challenges and opportunities for addressing the achievement gap in STEM fields for high-, low-, and medium-achieving countries; (b) focus on underrepresented groups in high, low, and medium achieving countries in terms of STEM knowledge and skills needed for 21st century careers; (c) systematically assess conference outputs to identify research, practice, and policies that are effective or at least promising to address STEM achievement gaps; (d) develop solutions and strategies to provide all children with equal opportunities to acquire knowledge and develop STEM skills; and (e)  provide an opportunity for countries with high-, low-, and medium- STEM achievement scores to share information and learn about achievement gap in STEM fields.

Six countries (South Korea, Singapore, Australia, United States, Turkey and the Ukraine) are selected to represent the range of achievement. Collaborations among multiple sectors, levels, and countries brought together by this conference will have a lasting impact on the development and enhancement of the quality of STEM education globally; this, in turn, will have direct positive effects on providing equal opportunities for all children in STEM fields.  The conference will provide an opportunity to provide a better understanding of the structural issues of achievement gap in STEM through the presentations on policies, research, and practices from an international perspective.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop brought together participants from the Americas, Africa, Europe, and Oceania to explore the challenges and opportunities to reduce achievement gaps in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Specifically, participants represented seven countries, 16 states, the District of Columbus, and one Reservation.   The conference was organized into three working groups, each with approximately 16-17 participants (including two-conveners to lead the discussion and a student note-taker), to produce recommendations for promising strategies and methods to address the global issues of achievement gaps in STEM education. The groups included science and mathematics teachers and administrators at the secondary and post-secondary levels, undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs, faculty, entrepreneurs, representatives from professional organizations, private foundation staff and others. Women comprised approximately half of each of the three working groups? co-convenors and plenary speakers. Similarly, half of the working groups were comprised of individuals employed at minority-serving institutions or organizations. 

Intellectual Merit

Education is essential for countries to improve the quality of life for their citizens. Because the achievement gap in STEM fields is a critical global problem, it is essential to address it from an international perspective.  Both developed and developing countries are making education reform a top priority.  By narrowing the achievement gap, countries develop well-educated citizenry with 21st century knowledge and skills that enhance not only individual life chances but also the social and economic well-being of the country. 

Conference participants were successful in identifying initial strategies for building an international community of stakeholders committed to engaging in collaborative efforts that could inform policies, research and practices to reduce STEM achievement disparities across the global landscape. The conference served as a catalyst for discourse on global solutions to address achievement gaps. Collaboration among participants from countries with differential levels of achievement gaps provided a variety of perspectives to enhance and advance our understanding of the STEM education opportunities that young people need and deserve.

Broader Impacts

STEM education is increasingly framed in global terms because most countries are focusing on strategies to develop and enhance their capacity to achieve international standards of technology and innovation. In an increasingly global society, it is essential to share the experiences?failures as well as successes?of strategies to narrow the achievement gap. The conference began to identify barriers as well as strategies for improving awareness and access to high-quality mathematics and science  education in a global perspective for under-participation of groups whether based on race, ethnicity, gender, and/or socio-economic status.  Participants identified some common global factors underlying the causes of achievement gaps in STEM education (e.g., poverty, teacher quality, sexism, racism, etc.).

The  working group white papers captured the following conference take-aways:

  • Inclusivity. Including participants from various professions and steps along the STEM pathway (from education to the workforce) is more holistic and synergistic than limiting participation to one category of stakeholders (e.g., education researchers)
  • Knowledge and information. Compared to international participants, a substantial proportion of U.S. participants were less knowledgeable about the extent to which the STEM achievement gaps were global phenomena. More discussion is needed from countries scoring average on the TIMSS assessments. Most of the invited representatives from these countries were unavailable to attend the conference because of financial reasons.
  • Scholarly literature. Since 2000, much of the literature on the international aspects of mathematics and science achievement gaps consists largely of highly quantitative academic journal articles with limited content on in-country inequality, especially multiracial/multicultural societies other than the U.S. With some exceptions, few books or reports accessible to a broad audience of stakeholders address the STEM achievement gaps from an international perspective.

External Evaluation Summary Findings

The external evaluation included an assessment of the pre-conference activities, the conference and post-conference interviews. In general, participants indicated that the conference is an excellent start in addressing the achievement gaps in the U.S. and internationally. The planned diversity of the participants and the expertise that was brought to bear on the problems were recognized as an important contributing factor in this effort. Conference survey results showed that the participants were very positive about their experiences (91.6% rating of excellent or good). While the overall ratings and comments were positive, two recommendations emerged that could be used in future workshops: (1) make the goals more focused by having specific questions to guide the discussions and (2) more travel funding is needed to increase the number of international participants to broaden the international perspectives in the working groups. Additionally, there was consensus among participants that 1.5 days was insufficient time to address all of the conference goals.

The working groups white papers were posted on the conference website. Following the conference, a small group of conference participants continued the discourse by organizing a session on inequities in education at an international learning conference.
